title: El Camino's Aaron Paul recaps all of Breaking Bad in three minutes
text:
Aaron Paul showed off his Breaking Bad knowledge as he summarised the entire show in less than three minutes and we’re seriously impressed.

Appearing on Jimmy Kimmel Live ahead of the launch on Friday of Netflix’s highly anticipated sequel to the popular series, El Camino, Aaron, who played Jesse Pinkman in AMC’s drug crime drama and its movie spin-off, gave fans a quick refresher of what happened across the show’s five seasons from 2008 and 2013.

Summarising Breaking Bad’s most important plot points (including Walt Jr.’s love of breakfast), Aaron whizzed through the show’s 62 episodes, reminding us just how jam-packed this show was and making us want to begin a rewatch immediately.

Not bad for one of the most complicated and intense TV shows of all time…

Six years after the show last aired, El Camino will see Aaron return to the iconic role of slacker drug dealer Jesse, picking up mere seconds after the explosive final saw Jesse escape his neo-Nazi captors.

‘In the wake of his dramatic escape from captivity, Jesse must come to terms with his past in order to forge some kind of future,’ teases the official synopsis.

All of Breaking Bad in two and a half minutes? Easy (Picture: Jimmy Kimmel Live)

With the show’s creator Vince Gilligan back at the helm for the film, it looks to be a Breaking Bad family reunion, with Skinny Pete (Charles Baker) and Badger (Matt Jones) starring in the film, which is said to feature 10 fan favourite characters from the original series.

However, one character who is unlikely to return (or at least be alive) is Walter White, or Heisenberg, played by Bryan Cranston.

After the show’s final episode saw Walt walk off to his presumed death of cancer, fans have spend years speculating what actually happened to the character, with Bryan’s appearance at last week’s El Camino premiere leading some to theorise that he would be appearing in the film.

If Walt does appear, it’ll only be in flashback, after Vince Gilligan finally confirmed what we’d all expected, saying: ‘Yes, Walter White is dead. Yes.’

El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie releases 11 October on Netflix.
